Award.AwardTitle: I-Corps: Smart Energy Analytic Disaggregation System
Award.AbstractNarration:
The broader impact/commercial potential of this I-Corps project is to provide home owners with reliable, real-time appliance energy information and guidance to manage their electricity consumption more efficiently and to facilitate the transition to distributed renewable energy generation and local microgrids through a low cost electricity data acquisition and analytic device. A smart energy system relies on balancing various internal power demands in order to maximize efficiency and minimize cost to users. This technology offers a low-cost, easily-installed device that can be used in residential settings, allowing consumers to identify which appliances are operating at a particular time and the real-time cost of electricity consumption. It can provide real-time data to the residential customers in order to facilitate broader energy management of distributed installations.

This I-Corps project is based on a smart energy analytic disaggregation system is built with open-source, embedded system composed of low-cost, off-the-shelf components, combining hardware and software. The system uses mathematical transformations to compress the data and machine-learning classification algorithms on the embedded processor to decompose building electric circuit load signals. Data are linked to appliance specific components by capturing and analyzing current and voltage data at a high sampling rate, differentiating among individual appliance signals, their harmonics, and unique signatures. The device has capacity for multiple sensors and can be updated continuously or daily via the existing internet infrastructure. The more devices and the longer it measures and analyzes, the better the algorithm becomes at appliance energy use identification.

POR.DRECONTENT:
The major goal of the Smart Energy Analytic Disaggregation System (SEADS) is to provide a platform for homeowners and small business residential communities to provide detailed information of their energy usage and save energy with one single low-cost device. This is achieved through the sub-millisecond sampling of current and voltage signal at the electricity interface behind the meter and in the sub-panels. After the team started NSF iCorps, team members interviewed 104 potential customers during the program and a total of 400+ after the program ended.

As a result of customer discovery outcomes, the team decided to focus on the B2B side and helping restaurants and grocery stores to monitor their refrigeration units to help in automation and service.

The major specific objective has been to identify a viable business model for SEADS through the Business Model Canvas. The team has formed a set of hypotheses, identified various value propositions and verified them through customer interviews.  One of the major activities has been customer discovery. The team has conducted 400+ customer interviews.  A substantial amount of time has been on driving the product and making it operational for the new market. Customer interviews have been instrumental in identifying the patent area and core part of the business.  After the initial iCorp program, the team has chosen refrigeration as the major market. After talking to customers including utility companies the team has identified thermal storage as a "Go direction" and plans to do a major demo with a utility on that.

The team has applied for major proposals, including NSF Smart & Connected Communities program. The team has also been pursuing patent through the University Patent Office. The team has identified refrigeration monitoring and thermal storage platform as the basis for the SEADs business model.

The team has also created a testbed for testing the performance of the SEADS. Furthermore, three Master student conducted their research on the platform. Millions of line of code have been added to the repo via 100+ Undergraduate students. The team is in the process of filing a patent through the university. 

The SEADS Team was a Finalist in the Caltech Flow program (DOE) and Energize California, and recently a semifinalist in the Rocket Fund. The team won the second prize ($3000) in the UCSC business competition sponsored by the Center for Innovation and Entrepreneurial Development.  The team has identified the Go market as the refrigeration monitoring and control system. iOS, Android, and web apps have been released to the app store. 

 

Three Master students (Eric Cao, Patrick Ayres, Abhiram Madenur Venkatesha) contributed to the SEADS project. Furthermore, SEADS provided 20 undergraduate students in the last year alone (100+ overall) the opportunity to work and learn on the various aspect of the software under the supervision of Adabi.  Application of the BMC and other I-corps tools also provided the basis for a UCSC course in Green Innovation and Entrepreneurship, with 20 students.

 

The team spent most of its time on customer discovery. Results will be disseminated to places such as electricity co-ops and to help utility companies manage the Duck Curve and provide stability to the grid. SEADS has been instrumental in training engineering students, many of whom now work at Google, Amazon, Apple, etc.

 

  • Provided opportunities for research, teaching and mentoring in science and engineering areas.
  • The project had an impact in training 100+ Electrical Engineering and Computer science students and preparing them for industry jobs. It also helped train students seeking experience in various disciplines. For example, at the spring quarter, students from the Visualization class worked on providing a new user interface for the users to better understand their energy data.
  • Provided opportunities for research and teaching in the relevant fields:
  • The data provided by SEADS has provided data scientist with a way to research various machine learning methods. The hardware provided an opportunity for hardware engineering students to test wireless charging strategies. 
  • improved the performance, skills, or attitudes of members of underrepresented groups that will improve their access to or retention in research, teaching, or other related professions;
  • Developed and disseminated new educational materials or provided scholarships:
  • Ronnie Lipschutz and Sue Carter have developed a new curriculum for their students to learn about customer discovery and business canvas model.
  • provided exposure to science and technology for practitioners, teachers, young people, or other members of the public?
  • 100+ students directly work on the SEADS project mainly from the undergraduate classes. 

SEADS now established itself as a constant project within the senior design. With the past four years, there has been constant improvement in the technology by many teams. SEADS GitHub team provides opportunities for students to learn about the code that students peers have written and improved that.
